Critical code studies (CCS) is an emerging academic subfield related to software studies, digital humanities, cultural studies, computer science, human-computer interface, and maker culture, with a focus on the cultural significance of computer code. CCS applies critical hermeneutics to interpret code, program architecture, and documentation within a socio-historical context. It holds that lines of code are not value-neutral and can be analyzed using theoretical approaches applied to other semiotic systems. Originally a method to read and explicate code like a work of literature, CCS also draws upon the concept of a cybertext as a "mechanical device for the production and consumption of verbal signs." Evidence of CCS's momentum since 2006 includes an article in The Chronicle of Higher Education, packed sessions at the Modern Language Association, academic conferences devoted to critical code studies, and a book dedicated t

content: Han Xin code is a 2D matrix barcode invented in 2007 by the Chinese company The Article Numbering Center of China to challenge the monopoly of QR code. It consists of black and white squares arranged in a grid and includes finder patterns and error correction for recognition with camera-based readers. It is also able to encode Chinese characters and has a larger capacity for numeric, English, and Chinese characters compared to QR code. Han Xin code is suitable for encoding English text and GS1 Application Identifiers data. It can also encode Unicode characters from other languages with special modes for lossless compression and URI encoding.

content: Léanord, a French computer brand founded in 1960, developed computers starting in the late 1970s. The first machines were based on Intel microprocessors and designed for automation and machine code learning. In 1978, the Silex microcomputer was released, using a licensed Apple II motherboard with a MOS 6502 and 32Kb RAM. It was expensive, priced at 29,000 Francs and included basic and Pascal interpreters and a disk operating system. The Sil'z was released in 1979, CP/M compatible, powered by a Zilog Z80 at 2.5 MHz, with two 5'' 1/4 320Kb disc drives. Later models, such as the Sil'z II, Sil'z III, and Sil'z IV, were released in the following years, with the Sil'z IV featuring a separate keyboard and monitor and adding a hard drive. The Sil'z 16, released in 1983, featured the Nanoréseau, a small network based on the RS422 standard, and later machines were PC compatible. Later models, such as the Challenger Elan series, were 16-bit ISA backplane machines. In 1989, Léanord merged with Intertechnique and was eventuall

Micral is a series of French microcomputers produced by R2E, starting with the Micral N in 1973, one of the first commercially available microprocessor-based computers. In 1986, it was recognized as the first personal computer using a microprocessor by three judges at The Computer Museum. The Micral N used the Intel 8008 microprocessor. The Computer History Museum now acknowledges the Micral as one of the earliest commercial non-kit personal computers, while the 1971 Kenbak-1 is considered the world's first "personal computer"

SMT Goupil was a French IT company founded in 1979 by Claude Perdrillat and specialized in producing microcomputers for French government agencies. Despite claiming to hold a significant market share, the company faced financial difficulties due to budget restrictions and competition from larger tech companies. Ultimately, SMT Goupil filed for bankruptcy in 1991 with a debt of 700 million francs and a turnover of 830 million francs in 1990.

In the 1980s, French company Thomson released a range of 8-bit computers based on the 6809E CPU. Variations in the MO and TO series were released from late 1982 to 1989, with incompatible software but compatible hardware. These computers were popular in France due to the government's educational program Informatique pour Tous, with around 100,000 installed in schools. However, export attempts were unsuccessful and by 1988 Thomson had only sold 60,000 of the predicted 150,000 computers, leading to the abandonment of computer development in the following year. content: Jean-Raymond Abrial (born 6 November 1938) is a French computer scientist known for inventing the Z and B formal methods. A graduate of the École Polytechnique, his 1974 paper Data Semantics established a formal approach to Data Models, influencing subsequent models. He is the creator of the Z notation, used for software specification, and initiated the B-Method for software development support. Abrial authored The B-Book and has worked as an independent consultant for much of his career. Elected as a Member of the Academia Europaea in 2006, he also served as an invited professor at ETH Zurich from 2004 to 2009.
categories: Members of the Department of Computer Science, University of Oxford

content: The University of Göttingen, also known as Georg August University, is a renowned public research university in Göttingen, Germany. Founded in 1734, it is the oldest university in Lower Saxony and has affiliations with 44 Nobel Prize winners. The university is a member of the U15 Group and the Coimbra Group, and has close ties to leading research institutions in Göttingen, including the Max Planck Society and the Fraunhofer Society. The Göttingen State and University Library is one of Germany's largest.

Prathyush and Mihir are India's fastest supercomputers, located at the Indian Institute of Tropical Meteorology (IITM) in Pune and the National Centre for Medium Range Weather Forecast (NCMRWF) in Noida. They were inaugurated in January 2018 by Dr. Harsh Vardhan, the Union Minister for science and technology. The word 'Pratyush' means the rising sun in Hindi. These High Performance Computing (HPC) units have a combined peak power of 6.8 PetaFlops, making it the first multi-PetaFlops supercomputer in India. They are used for weather forecasting and climate monitoring, helping to make better forecasts for events like monsoons, fishing, air quality, tsunamis, cyclones, earthquakes, and natural calamities such as floods and droughts. content: SAGA-220 is a supercomputer built by the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) with a speed of 220 teraflops. It was unveiled in 2011 and is located at the Satish Dhawan Supercomputing Facility at Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre. The system uses 400 NVIDIA Tesla C2070 GPUs and 400 Intel Quad Core Xeon CPUs, and cost about INR 140,000,000 to build. It consumes only about 150 kW. SAGA-220 is used by scientists to solve complex aeronautical problems and has been hinted to be used for designing future space launch vehicles. As of June 2015, it was ranked 422nd on the Top500 list.

content:
In April 2010, the Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology in India commissioned the Human-Centred Design & Computing Group at C-DAC, Pune to prepare a National Study Report on Digital Preservation Requirements in India. The objective was to assess the current state of digital preservation in India and make recommendations for the National Digital Preservation Program, involving stakeholders from various sectors.

Experts from 24 organizations participated in the national expert group, representing domains such as e-governance, archives, cultural heritage, health, science, education, insurance, banking, and law. They submitted position papers outlining short-term and long-term digital preservation plans for their respective domains. The study report, presented in two volumes, included recommendations for the National Digital Preservation Program and position papers by the expert group members.

The report covered international digital preservation projects, legal imperatives, technical challenges, and standards. One key recommendation was to align various Acts with the Information Technology Act to address digital preservation needs. This recommendation was validated in 2018 when the Indian judiciary began drafting electronic evidence rules under the Indian Evidence Act. A Joint Committee of High Court Judges visited C-DAC, Pune in March 2018 to examine technical aspects of the proposed rules.

content: Ritchie Street in Chennai, India is a bustling hub for electronic goods from China and Korea. It is notorious for selling illegally copied content and has been listed as a notorious market for selling counterfeit software and media. The street started as a radio market and now offers a wide range of electronics and robotics. With over 2,500 shops and 15,000 employees, it is the second largest electronic market in India after Nehru Place in New Delhi. The market buzzes from 11 am to 10 pm, attracting working professionals and students seeking good deals.

TIFRAC was India's first computer, developed at the Tata Institute of Fundamental Research in Mumbai. It was operational in 1956 and formally commissioned in 1960 by Jawaharlal Nehru. The computer had 2,700 vacuum tubes, 1,700 germanium diodes, and 12,500 resistors, with 2,048 40-bit words of ferrite core memory. The main assembly was housed in a large steel rack and had a cathode ray tube display system for output. The software was written in machine code. The first digital computer in India was the British-built HEC 2M, imported and installed at the Indian Statistical Institute in 1955, while the institute had previously developed a small analog computer in 1953.

content: Minix 3 is a small, Unix-like operating system that is licensed under BSD-3-Clause. Its main goal is to be fault-tolerant and self-repairing without user intervention. It is designed for embedded systems and education. As of 2017, Minix 3 supports IA-32 and ARM processors and can run on emulators and virtual machines. A port to PowerPC architecture is in development. The latest release is 3.4.0 rc6 from 2017, and the project has been dormant since 2018. Minix 3 is believed to have inspired the Intel Management Engine OS used with Skylake and Kaby Lake processors. It was debated that Minix could have been the most widely used OS on x86/AMD64 processors

content: Schoonschip, developed in 1963 by Martinus J. G. Veltman, was an early computer algebra system used in particle physics. The name refers to a Dutch expression meaning "to make a clean sweep". Veltman initially created the program to compute the quadrupole moment of the W boson, which involved a complex calculation. The initial version ran on an IBM 7094 mainframe, and was later ported to other mainframes and microprocessor systems. Schoonschip had an impact on the development of FORM, and contacts with Veltman were important for Stephen Wo

content:
THE系统是由Edsger W. Dijkstra领导的团队设计的计算机操作系统，于1965年至1966年在专著中描述，并于1968年出版。Dijkstra从未为系统命名；“THE”只是荷兰埃因霍温科技大学（Technische Hogeschool Eindhoven）的缩写。THE系统主要是一个批处理系统，支持多任务处理，但并非多用户操作系统。它类似于SDS 940，但“THE系统中的进程集合是静态的”。

THE系统显然引入了第一种基于软件的分页虚拟内存形式（Electrologica X8不支持硬件内存管理），使程序不再被迫使用物理位置上的鼓式存储器。它通过使用改进的ALGOL编译器（Dijkstra系统唯一支持的编程语言）来“自动生成对系统例程的调用，确保所需信息在内存中，必要时进行交换”。分页虚拟内存也用于缓冲输入/输出(I/O)设备数据和操作系统代码的大部分部分，以及几乎所有的ALGOL 60编译器。在这个系统中，信号量首次被用作程序构造。

《任天堂杂志系统》是澳大利亚的官方任天堂杂志。该杂志在2000年之前出版了七年，是英国《官方任天堂杂志》（也称为《任天堂杂志系统》）的分支。2008年11月12日，宣布了一本新的官方澳大利亚任天堂杂志。

澳大利亚版本最初由Trielle Corporation出版，每期68页。1993年4月出版的第一期以《超级马里奥乐园2》为封面。它是澳大利亚的官方任天堂杂志，并且对质量不佳的视频游戏进行了严厉的批评，这类游戏的得分通常只有30多分。杂志经常包括与任天堂产品无关的新闻和文章，从虚拟现实的概念到当时销量最高的投币式街机游戏信息。

从1996年1月的第34期开始，Catalyst Publishing接管了杂志的出版，但保留了期数编号。《任天堂杂志系统》的最后一期是2000年8月的第89期。

content: The British Informatics Olympiad (BIO) is an annual computer-programming competition for students under 19 in full-time pre-university education in mainland Britain. It consists of a preliminary 3-question, 3-hour exam and a final round at Trinity College, Cambridge. The top 15 students are invited to the finals, where they solve more difficult problems. To reach the final, a score of 75 to 90 out of 100 is typically required. The top four students form the British team for the International Olympiad in Informatics, with one or two reserves. content:
Micro Live was a BBC2 TV series produced by David Allen as part of the BBC's Computer Literacy Project. It followed earlier series like The Computer Programme and focused on live broadcasts. The series began with a two-hour special in 1983 and continued as a regular one-hour series starting in October 1984. It later transitioned to a weekly half-hour format, airing its final episode in 1987.

Micro Live had a broader scope than previous computer series and featured a variety of microcomputers, not just the BBC Micro. The show also included stories from the United States and highlighted significant milestones, such as the first on-air transatlantic mobile phone call. The series had a less formal feel due to its live nature, making it unique among computer programs at the time.

content: Raspberry Pi is a series of small single-board computers developed in the UK by the Raspberry Pi Foundation. Originally aimed at promoting basic computer science education, it became popular for diverse uses due to its low cost, modularity, and open design. The Foundation established Raspberry Pi (Trading) Ltd. to develop their computers and became an educational charity. Most are made in Wales, with some also made in China and Japan. In 2015, Raspberry Pi became the best-selling British computer, surpassing the ZX Spectrum. In 2021, Raspberry Pi (Trading) Ltd changed its name to Raspberry Pi Ltd. In June 2024, it became a public company, trading under the name RPI on the London Stock Exchange.

content: BS 7799 was a British standard for Information Security Management first published in 1995. It outlined 127 information security controls in 10 sections and was later revised to encourage users to determine their own risks and objectives. BS 7799-1 was adopted as ISO/IEC 17799 in 2000 and later renumbered as ISO/IEC 27002. BS 7799-2 was published in 1999 as a specification for conformity assessment and certification, eventually adopted as ISO/IEC 27001. BS 7799-3, published in 2005, focuses on information security risk management and was adapted as ISO/IEC 27005 in 2008. It continues to evolve, with a proposal to simplify the guidance for smaller organizations in 2023.

The London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE) is a public research university in London, England, and a member institution of the University of London. Founded in 1895, LSE has more than 11,000 students, with just under seventy percent from outside the UK, and 3,300 staff. The university has the sixth-largest endowment of any university in the UK and in 2022/23, it had an income of £466.1 million, with £39.6 million from research grants.

LSE is organized into 25 academic departments and institutes, conducting teaching and research across a range of pure and applied social sciences. The university is a member of the Russell Group, Association of Commonwealth Universities, and the European University Association, and is considered part of the "golden triangle" of research universities in the south east of England. In the 2021 Research Excellence Framework, the school had the third highest grade point average, tied with Cambridge.

content: Corrected Block TEA (XXTEA) is a block cipher designed to address weaknesses in the original Block TEA. However, it is vulnerable to a chosen-plaintext attack requiring 259 queries and negligible work. The algorithm was designed by Roger Needham and David Wheeler of the Cambridge Computer Laboratory in 1998 and is not patented. XXTEA operates on variable-length blocks, using a round function that makes use of immediate neighbors in processing each word. It is likely more efficient than XTEA for longer messages.

Proof of space (PoS) is a consensus algorithm that demonstrates legitimate interest in a service by allocating memory or disk space to solve a challenge. It was formulated in 2013 and is similar to proof of work (PoW), but uses storage to earn cryptocurrency. PoS is seen as a fairer and greener alternative to PoW due to its lower energy cost. In 2014, Signum (formerly Burstcoin) became the first practical implementation of PoS and is still actively developed. Other implementations like SpaceMint and Chia have been released, but some have faced criticism for increasing demand and shortening the life of storage devices.

content: Numerical weather prediction has evolved significantly since its manual attempt in the 1920s. The advent of computers and simulations in the 1950s reduced computation time, allowing for more accurate forecasts. Global forecasting models and limited area models for regional forecasts were developed, leading to the first climate models and improved tracking of tropical cyclones and air quality. Model output statistics (MOS) were developed in the 1970s and 1980s to correct forecast model output based on atmospheric dynamics. Despite advancements in supercomputing power, the forecast skill of numerical weather models only extends to about two weeks into the future due to observational limitations and the chaotic nature of the equations used. Ensemble forecasts have been utilized since the 1990s to define forecast uncertainty and extend weather forecasting beyond the two-week limit.

content:
Women were pioneers in early programming and made substantial contributions to the industry. From scientific computations in the 18th century to designing the first algorithm for a computer by Ada Lovelace, women played a significant role. Grace Hopper designed the first compiler for a programming language, and women dominated programming work up to World War II. However, after the 1960s, the importance of women in computing decreased as modern software evolved.

The gender disparity in computing has been examined, but firm explanations are lacking. Nevertheless, women continued to make significant contributions, and efforts were made to address the gender imbalance. In the 21st century, women have held leadership roles in multiple tech companies, including Meg Cushing Whitman at Hewlett Packard Enter

content: The Stanhope Demonstrator, created by Charles Stanhope, was the first machine to solve logic problems. In 1775, the first model was constructed with colored slides in a brass frame, demonstrating solutions to syllogistic problems involving objects with two different properties. This form of inference anticipated the numerically definite syllogism outlined by Augustus De Morga

The arithmometer, patented in France by Thomas de Colmar in 1820, was the first digital mechanical calculator used daily in offices. It could add, subtract, multiply, and divide effectively, launching the mechanical calculator industry in 1851. Known for its reliability and accuracy, it was the only type of mechanical calculator in commercial production from 1851 to 1890. Eventually, about twenty European companies built clones of the arithmometer until World War I.

The difference engine, invented by Charles Babbage in the 1820s, is an automatic mechanical calculator used to tabulate polynomial functions. It derives its name from the method of divided differences, allowing for the interpolation or tabulation of functions using a small set of polynomial c

Discrete transistors became more reliable and affordable than vacuum tubes from 1953 to 1959, leading to the development of semiconductor memory in the mid-to-late 1960s and the microprocessor in the early 1970s. content: Google was launched in 1998 to market Google Search, the most used web-based search engine. Developed by students at Stanford University, the company quickly grew and went public in 2004. Google launched various products, including Google News (2002), Gmail (2004), Google Maps (2005), and Google Chrome (2008). In 2015, Google became a subsidiary of Alphabet Inc. The company also established partnerships with NASA, AOL, Sun Microsystems, and others, and created Google.org, a charitable offshoot. The name "Google" is a misspelling of "Googol," signifying the search engine's ability to provide large quantities of information.

content:
International Business Machines (IBM) is a global corporation specializing in computer technology and IT consulting. The company originated from the amalgamation of enterprises dedicated to automating routine business transactions, notably pioneering punched card-based data tabulating machines and time clocks. In 1911, these entities were unified under the umbrella of the Computing-Tabulating-Recording Company (CTR).

Thomas J. Watson became the general manager in 1914 and later the President in 1915. By 1924, the company rebranded as "International Business Machines" and diversified its offerings to include electric typewriters and office equipment. IBM began its forays into computing in the 1940s and 1950s, and in the 1960s introduced the System/360 family of mainframe computers.

IBM encountered difficulties in the late 1980s and 1990s, marked by substantial losses. The company struggled to adapt to the growing Unix open systems and personal computer revolutions. IBM responded with a Unix line and a range of personal computers, but faced competition from clone manufacturers offering cost-effective alternatives.

Through strategic reorganizations, IBM sustained its status as one of the world's largest computer companies and systems integrators. As of 2014, the company had over 400,000 employees globally and held the highest number of patents among U.S.-based technology firms. IBM employees were recognized with numerous accolades, including Nobel Prizes, Turing Awards, National Medals of Technology, and National Medals of Science.

In response, some websites complied and removed the key, while others continued to share it. The situation escalated when Digg received a DMCA notice and removed articles about the controversy, sparking a digital revolt where users spread the key online. The AACS LA called this an "interesting new twist".

The Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) is a symmetric block cipher ratified as a standard by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) of the United States. The process of choosing AES, which lasted from 1997 to 2000, was more open and transparent than its predecessor, the Data Encryption Standard (DES). This won praise from the cryptographic community and increased confidence in the winning algorithm, as many were suspicious of backdoors in DES.

content: The Babington Plot was a scheme in 1586 to assassinate Queen Elizabeth I and place her Catholic cousin, Mary, Queen of Scots, on the English throne. This led to Mary's execution due to a letter she sent consenting to the assassination of Elizabeth. The goal was to have Spain and the Catholic League in France invade England and restore the old religion. The plot was discovered by Elizabeth's spymaster Sir Francis Walsingham and used to remove Mary as a claimant to the English throne. Chief conspirators were Anthony Babington and John Ballard. The plot was revealed through the work of double agents and spies, culminating in Mary's letter ordering the assassination of Elizabeth. Mary was later betrayed by her secretaries, leading to her execution.

BATCO, or Battle Code, is a hand-held, paper-based encryption system used at a low, front line level in the British Army. Introduced in the 1980s, it became largely obsolete by 2010 due to the secure Bowman radios. It consists of a code on vocabulary cards and cipher sheets for encryption. content: The Battle of Midway, a pivotal naval battle during World War II, took place from 4-7 June 1942 in the Pacific Theater. The U.S. Navy, led by Admirals Nimitz, Fletcher, and Spruance, decisively defeated the Imperial Japanese Navy, inflicting heavy damage. The Japanese, looking to extend their defensive perimeter, hoped to trap American aircraft carriers, but faulty planning and U.S. codebreaking undermined their strategy. The battle resulted in the sinking of four Japanese carriers and one cruiser, and the loss of one American carrier and a destroyer. Following Midway and the Solomon Islands campaign, Japan's ability to replace losses was insufficient, while the U.S. had the industrial and training capacity to do so. Many consider Midway a turning point in the Pacific War.

content:
The Beale ciphers are a set of three ciphertexts that allegedly contain the location of a buried treasure worth over 43 million US dollars. The first unsolved text describes the location, the second ciphertext details the contents of the treasure, and the third unsolved text lists the names of the treasure's owners and their next of kin.

The story originates from an 1885 pamphlet called The Beale Papers, detailing treasure buried by a man named Thomas J. Beale in Virginia in about 1820. Beale entrusted the encrypted messages to an innkeeper named Robert Morriss before disappearing. The innkeeper eventually gave the messages to a friend, who spent years trying to decode them and only managed to solve one.

Several attempts have been made to decode the remaining messages and locate the treasure, but all have failed. There are arguments that the entire story is a hoax, including historical records that cast doubt on the existence of Thomas J. Beale. An analysis suggests that the documents could not have been written at the alleged time, and the writing style indicates that Beale was likely James B. Ward, who brought the Beale Pap

content: The Cipher Bureau was a Polish military unit responsible for intercepting and analyzing signals, as well as both creating and breaking codes and ciphers. It was established in 1919 and played a crucial role in Poland's victory during the Polish-Soviet War. By 1932, the Bureau had successfully decrypted Germany's Enigma ciphers and also broke Soviet codes. In 1939, they shared their decryption techniques with French and British intelligence, providing the Allies with a significant advantage in World War II. This transfer of intelligence and technology, known as Ultra, proved instrumental in the Allies' victory.

content:
Lossless compression allows the original data to be perfectly reconstructed from the compressed data with no loss of information, making it possible due to statistical redundancy in most real-world data. However, no lossless compression algorithm can shrink the size of all possible data, as some data will get longer by at least one symbol or byte.

Compression algorithms are effective for human- and machine-readable documents, but cannot shrink the size of random data without redundancy. Lossless data compression is used in various applications, such as the ZIP file format and the GNU tool gzip. It is also utilized within lossy data compression technologies.

Lossless compression is important in cases where the original and decompressed data must be identical, such as in executable programs, text documents, and source code. Additionally, some image and audio file formats use only lossless compression for archiving or production purposes, while smaller lossy audio fi

A chatbot is a software application designed to simulate human conversation through text or voice interactions. Modern chatbots use artificial intelligence to maintain a conversation with a user in natural language, and have gained attention due to the popularity of models such as OpenAI's ChatGPT, Microsoft's Copilot, and Google's Gemini. Chatbots are commonly used in customer service and support, and companies are leveraging advanced AI technologies in various industries. However, chatbots can produce inaccurate or fabricated content, known as ‘hallucinations’, leading to concerns about the potential impact on content generation and consumption.

content: The Gödel Prize is an annual award for outstanding papers in theoretical computer science, jointly given by EATCS and ACM SIGACT. Named after Kurt Gödel, it has been awarded since 1993 at ICALP and STOC conferences. Eligible papers must be published in a refereed journal within the last 14 years, and the prize includes a reward of US$5000. A committee of six members selects the winner, and the prize recognizes individual impact in the field like the Knuth Prize.

content: The Gordon Bell Prize, presented by the Association for Computing Machinery, acknowledges outstanding achievements in high-performance computing applications, serving to track progress in parallel computing. Established in 1987 and funded by Gordon Bell, the prize includes a $10,000 cash award. Alan Karp, a numerical analyst, established a nominal prize before the Gordon Bell Prize. Individuals or teams can apply for the award by submitting a technical paper through the SC conference submissions process.

content: The J.W. Graham Medal in Computing and Innovation is awarded annually by the University of Waterloo and the Faculty of Mathematics to recognize leadership and innovative contributions to the university and the Canadian computer industry. Established in 1994, the award honors Canadian computer industry veteran James Wesley Graham, known as "Wes Graham." Graham, born in 1932, was a graduate of the University of Toronto and joined the University of Waterloo faculty in 1959, where he led the development of the WATFOR series of compilers, formed the "Computer Systems Group," and was responsible for spin-off organizations like Watcom. content: The Loebner Prize was an annual competition in artificial intelligence that awarded prizes to the most human-like computer programs, using a standard Turing test format. Launched in 1990 by Hugh Loebner, it was later organized by the AISB at Bletchley Park, and associated with various institutions. The competition has been controversial within the field of artificial intelligence, with prominent critic Marvin Minsky calling it a publicity stunt. The format changed for the 2019 competition, with the chatbots judged by the public and no human competitors. The prize has been reported as defunct as of 2020.

content: The Royal Society Milner Award, given by the London-based Royal Society, recognizes exceptional achievement in computer science by a European researcher. The award is named after Robin Milner and is supported by Microsoft Research. Winners, who must be active researchers in computer science in Europe, receive a bronze medal, a £5,000 prize, and the opportunity to deliver a public lecture at the Society. The recipients are selected by the Council of the Royal Society based on the recommendation of the Milner Award Committee, which consists of Fellows of the Royal Society, Members of the Académie des sciences (France), and Members of Leopoldina (Germany). content: The RSA Conference (RSAC) Award for Excellence in Mathematics is an annual honor recognizing innovations and contributions in the field of cryptography. The award committee, associated with the Cryptographer's Track committee at the RSA Conference (CT-RSA), nominates pioneers in the field whose work has lasting value, typically given for lifetime achievements. Nominees are often affiliated with universities or involved in information technology research and development. The award, cosponsored by the International Association for Cryptologic Research, acknowledges the significance of cryptography in information technology, including its impact on the Internet, cellular networks, cloud computing, information privacy, and security. content: The Seymour Cray Computer Engineering Award, also known as the Seymour Cray Award, is given by the IEEE Computer Society to recognize significant contributions in high-performance computing. It honors scientists who exhibit the creativity of Seymour Cray, founder of Cray Research, Inc. and a pioneer of supercomputing. Cray was an American electrical engineer and supercomputer architect who designed the world's fastest computers for decades and founded Cray Research. In 1996, one year after Cray's death, the award was created in his honor. The winner receives a crystal memento, certificate, and US$10,000 honorarium. The first recipient in 1999 was John Cocke.

content: The ACM A. M. Turing Award, presented by the Association for Computing Machinery, is a prestigious prize that recognizes significant and long-lasting contributions to the field of computer science. Named after British mathematician Alan Turing, it is often referred to as the "Nobel Prize of Computing." The award has been accompanied by a prize of US$1 million since 2014, with support from Google. The first recipient was Alan Perlis in 1966, and the youngest recipient was Donald Knuth in 1974, while the oldest was Alfred Aho in 2020. content:
Polynomial factorization, a key component of computer algebra systems, expresses a polynomial as the product of irreducible factors with coefficients in the same domain. The first algorithm was published in 1793, and significant progress has been made since the advent of computer algebra systems in circa 1965.

Modern algorithms and computers can efficiently factor univariate polynomials of degree over 1000 with coefficients containing thousands of digits. Even in the case of factoring over rational numbers and number fields, a crucial step is the factorization of the polynomial over a finite field. Erich Kaltofen noted in 1982 that algorithms can factor uni- or multivariate polynomials of moderate size in just

content: Polynomial factorization in mathematics involves breaking down a polynomial into irreducible factors. This is theoretically possible and unique for polynomials with coefficients in any field, but practical algorithms are limited to finite fields, rational numbers, or their extensions. Factorization algorithms for multivariate polynomials ultimately reduce to the univariate case. This process has applications in coding theory, cryptography, and computational number theory. content: A Gröbner basis is a generating set of an ideal in a polynomial ring over a field, used in computational algebraic geometry and commutative algebra. It simplifies the deduction of properties of the ideal and associated algebraic variety, making it a practical tool for solving systems of polynomial equations and computing images of algebraic varieties. Gröbner basis computation is a generalization of Euclid's algorithm and Gaussian elimination. Introduced by Bruno Buchberger in 1965, they were named after his advisor Wolfgang Gröbner. The theory has been extended to other structures, including polynomials over principal ideal rings and non-commutative rings.

content: 1978年，数论家约翰·波拉德提出了波拉德的袋鼠算法，也称为波拉德的lambda算法，用于解决离散对数问题。该算法可在任何有限循环群中使用，不仅局限于模素数p的单位乘法群中。该算法可用于计算离散对数问题，是计算数论和计算代数领域的重要算法之一。

The greatest common divisor (GCD) of two polynomials in algebra is a polynomial with the highest degree that is a factor of both. When dealing with univariate polynomials over a field, the polynomial GCD can be computed using the Euclidean algorithm with long division. The polynomial GCD is defined up to multiplication by an invertible constant. This concept shares similarities with the integer GCD, and properties deduced from the Euclidean algorithm can be extended to univariate polynomials. The roots of the polynomial GCD give information about the common roots of the original polynomials and can be used to compute square-free factorization. The GCD also applies to multivariate polynomials over a field or the ring of integers, and algorithms exist to compute it. These algorithms are used in computer algebra systems to simplify fractions, and modern theory of polynomial GCD has been developed to satisfy the need for efficiency in these systems.

content: This article discusses the resultant of two polynomials, which is a polynomial expression of their coefficients that equals zero when the polynomials share a common root or factor. The resultant is used in number theory and can be efficiently computed on a computer. It is a fundamental tool in computer algebra and is used for various purposes, such as cylindrical algebraic decomposition and integration of rational functions. The resultant of n homogeneous polynomials in n variables, also known as the multivariate resultant, is a generalization introduced by Macaulay and is a key tool in elimination theory, along with Gröbner bases.

The algorithm is a decision procedure for determining if a function has an elementary function as an indefinite integral, but it does not always succeed in identifying whether the antiderivative of a given function can be expressed in terms of elementary functions. content: Sturm's theorem, based on a variant of Euclid's algorithm for polynomials, uses the Sturm sequence to count the distinct real roots of a univariate polynomial in a given interval. It can also locate these roots by counting changes in the sequence's values at the interval's bounds. While the fundamental theorem of algebra provides the overall number of complex roots, Sturm's theorem isolates and counts distinct real roots, creating the oldest real-root isolation algorithm. Although less efficient than other methods for computing over the reals, it is fundamental for the theoretical study of computational complexity in the first-order theory of real numbers. The theorem was discovered by Jacques Charles François Sturm in 1829.

content:
Symbolic regression (SR) is a form of regression analysis that explores mathematical expressions to find the best model for a given dataset, balancing accuracy and simplicity.

Initial expressions are created by randomly combining mathematical components like operators, functions, constants, and variables. Methods for solving the SR problem include genetic programming, Bayesian methods, neural networks, and the Universal Functions Originator (UFO) method.

SR does not rely on a predefined model, avoiding human bias and unknown gaps in knowledge. It aims to uncover dataset relationships without imposing a model structure. The fitness function considers error metrics and complexity measures to reveal underlying structure without overfitting.

SR can prioritize accuracy and simplicity separately, leading to a Pareto front of optimum solutions, or combine them using principles like minimum description length. It is a NP-hard problem, meaning it may not always find the best expression in polynomial time, but exact solutions are possible for less complex equations.

content: The Green Power Usage Effectiveness (GPUE) is a proposed measurement of sustainable energy usage and carbon footprint per usable kilowatt hour (kWh) in computer data centers. It measures how effectively a data center uses its power, specifically how much power is used by computing equipment. It is an addition to the Power Usage Effectiveness (PUE) definition and was first proposed by Greenqloud. The Green Grid has developed the PUE metric to measure a data center's effectiveness in getting power to IT equipment. PUE tells how much extra energy is needed for each usable kWh for IT equipment due to power going into cooling and power loss. The PUE can change depending on measurements' location, timing, and timespan, and some issues with PUE are being addressed with the PUEx definition. GPUE "weighs" the PUE to better see which data centers are the greenest in terms of emitting the least amount of CO2 due to sustainable or unsustainable energy sources. GPUE is calculated using a weighted sum of energy sources and their lifecycle KG CO2/KWh. For example, with a PUE of 1.20 and a 50/50 coal/hydro energy source, the GPUE would be 1.84 or 0.64 kg CO2 per usable kWh.

content: The Weissman score, developed by Tsachy Weissman and Vinith Misra, is a performance metric for lossless compression. It compares the time and compression ratio of measured applications with those of a standard compressor, using the formula W=αr/r¯log(T¯)/log(T). The score has been used by Dropbox to prioritize compression speed over ratio in most cases.

content: The Whetstone benchmark, first developed in 1972, evaluates computer performance by measuring the execution speeds of a set of ALGOL 60 instructions. It was originally created at the Technical Support Unit of the Department of Trade and Industry in the United Kingdom. The benchmark was designed to be practical and was later improved to measure performance in millions of Whetstone Instructions Per Second (MWIPS) to account for increased computer speeds. Source code and pre-compiled versions for PCs in various programming languages are available. The benchmark primarily measures floating-point arithmetic performance, while the Dhrystone benchmark is used for integer and string operations.

content: An emulator in computing allows one computer system (the host) to behave like another computer system (the guest), either through hardware or software. It enables the host system to run software or use peripheral devices designed for the guest system. Emulation can be seen in printers that emulate HP LaserJet printers to run software written for HP printers. Video game enthusiasts use emulators to play classic arcade games from the 1980s and old video game consoles. A hardware emulator takes the form of a hardware device, like the DOS-compatible card in some 1990s-era Macintosh computers. The Church-Turing thesis states that theoretically, any operating environment can be emulated in another environment, but in practice, it can be difficult, particularly when the behavior of the system to be emulated is not documented. Timing constraints can also affect the performance of software inside the emulation.

Hardware backdoors are malicious codes embedded in computer chip hardware or firmware, known as hardware Trojans. They undermine security in smartcards and cryptoprocessors, and have been a concern for c

A hardware compatibility list (HCL) is a database of computer hardware that is compatible with a specific operating system or device management software. It includes whole computer systems, motherboards, sound cards, and video cards. HCLs can be maintained centrally or by user reviews. Most operating systems have an official HCL on their website.

A hardware reset, or hard reset, re-initializes a computer's core hardware components, ending all current software operations and booting the system into firmware to restart the operating system. It is essential during the power-on process and can be triggered by a physical reset button, watchdog timers, or software intervention. User-initiated hard resets can be used to restore unresponsive devices, but may result in data corruption. This can be done by pressing a dedicated reset button or holding a combination of buttons on mobile devices. Some devices may require the user to hold the power button to cut power and then turn the computer back on. In some systems, pressing and releasing the power button initiates a hard reset, while holdin

content: Hardware security, originating from cryptographic engineering, involves secure hardware design, access control, secure key storage, and code authenticity. A hardware security module (HSM) is a physical device that manages digital keys for authentication and cryptoprocessing. Providers differentiate hardware security from software security by using non-Turing-machine logic, often implemented with FPGAs. Hardware backdoors and hardware Trojans are malicious modifications to electronic systems. Physical unclonable functions (PUFs) are hard-to-predict, easy-to-evaluate physical entities used in high-security applications. Organizations must also address internal threats to sensitive data and resources.

content:
A Hardware Trojan (HT) is a malicious modification to the circuitry of an integrated circuit, characterized by its physical representation and behavior. The payload of an HT includes the activities it executes when triggered, such as bypassing or disabling security measures and leaking confidential information. HTs can also disable, damage, or destroy the entire chip or its components.

Hardware Trojans can be introduced as hidden "front-doors" in computer chip designs, using pre-made ASIC semiconductor IP Cores from non-reputable sources or inserted internally by rogue employees. One paper published by IEEE in 2015 explains how a hardware design containing a Trojan could leak a cryptographic key over an antenna or network connection with the right trigger.

It is often integrated into the processor's instruction set, such as the AES instruction set on x86 and ARM architectures. Some systems use a separate cryptography module as a secure coprocessor, like the IBM 4758 or IBM 4764. This includes the call request time, selection time, and post selection time.

A data center, known as a data centre in Commonwealth English, is a facility used to house computer systems and associated components. It is essential for business continuity and typically includes redundant or backup components for power supply, data communication connections, and security devices. With estimated global electricity consumption of 240-340 TWh in 2022, data centers can vary widely in terms of size, power requirements, and overall structure. content: Data communication is the transfer of data over communication channels, such as copper wires, optical fibers, and wireless radio spectrum. The data is represented as electromagnetic signals, and can be transmitted using analog or digital methods. Analog transmission conveys information using continuously varying signals, while digital transmission involves digitized analog signals or born-digital bitstreams. Both baseband and passband components can be considered part of a digital signal, depending on the definition used.

Datakit is a virtual circuit switch developed by Sandy Fraser at Bell Labs for local-area and wide-area networks and widely used by Regional Bell Operating Companies. It uses a cell relay protocol similar to Asynchronous Transfer Mode and is still in use by major U.S. telephone companies. Datakit supports various interfaces and operates over multiple media, including fiber optic links and Ethernet. The Information Systems Network (ISN) was the pre-version of Datakit. By the late 1990s, new technologies, such as IP and Ethernet, superseded Datakit, leading to its eventual discontinuation by Lucent Technologies. Datatek Applications, a firm founded by former Lucent employees, aimed to support remaining Datakit users, but eventually went out of business in January 2018.

A decentralized autonomous organization (DAO), also known as a decentralized autonomous corporation (DAC), is managed by a decentralized computer program, utilizing blockchain for voting and finances. DAOs are member-owned communities without centralized leadership, with unclear legal status. The infamous example of The DAO, designed for venture capital funding, was hacked and lost millions in cryptocurrency. The governance of DAOs is controversial due to the potential concentration of power through token allocation and distribution.

content: The Defense Information System Network (DISN) has been the United States Department of Defense's enterprise telecommunications network for 40 years. It consists of three major segments: the sustaining base, the long-haul transport infrastructure, and the deployed warfighter. DISN provides services such as Global Content Delivery, Data Services, Satellite Communications, Voice Services, and more, catering to the needs of military organizations and supporting interoperability with allied nations and the Intelligence Community. The technical core of DISN is the Global Information Grid-Bandwidth Expansion (GIG-BE) program, completed from 2002-2006, which significantly improved national security intelligence and command and control capabilities.

content: Etherloop is a hybrid technology that combines aspects of Ethernet with other technologies to achieve results not possible with either technology alone. It was originally developed in the 1990s to provide high-speed data communication access to residential customers over standard telephone lines. This allowed telephone companies to compete with cable TV providers. Etherloop combines Ethernet protocol concepts with Digital subscriber line (DSL) technology to facilitate voice and data transmission on legacy phone lines over several kilometers. By using digital signal processors (DSP), Etherloop can achieve high-quality, high-speed data transmission. The technology has broader applications beyond its original purpose, including use in automotive intra-vehicle communication in the 2020s. It refers to a high-performance computing system consisting of storage, networking, and parallel processing functions linked by high bandwidth interconnects. The fundamental components are "nodes" (processors, memory, and peripherals) and "links" (functional connections between nodes). The term has also been used in association with storage area networks and switched fabric networking. content: Failover is the process of switching to a backup server, system, hardware component, or network in the event of a failure. It is essential for systems that require high reliability and continuous availability. Failover can be automated, using a "heartbeat" system to detect failures and switch to the backup, or require human intervention. Failback, on the other hand, is the process of restoring the original system after a failure, while virtualization technology has made failover less reliant on physical hardware. Microsoft SQL Server also uses failover technology to ensure high availability and reliability, allowing the database to switch to a backup node in case of issues and then failback once the issues are resolved.

However, FMC has not developed as expected due to alleged lack of demand, leading to a pessimistic outlook from the International Telecommunication Union (ITU).

content:
计算机网络中，主机模型是设计像Microsoft Windows或Linux这样的网络操作系统的TCP/IP堆栈的一个选项。当单播数据包到达主机时，IP必须确定数据包是否本地目的地（其目的地与主机接口分配的地址匹配）。如果IP堆栈实现了弱主机模型，它会接受任何本地目的地数据包，而不管数据包接收的网络接口如何。如果IP堆栈实现了强主机模型，它只会接受本地目的地数据包，如果数据包中的目的地IP地址与接收数据包的网络接口分配的IP地址匹配。

弱主机模型提供了更好的网络连接性（例如，可以使用普通工具轻松找到到达主机的任何数据包），但也使主机容易受到基于多重主机的网络攻击的影响。例如，在某些配置中，运行弱主机模型的系统连接到VPN时，同一子网上的其他系统可能会危及VPN连接的安全性。运行强主机模型的系统不容易受到这种类型的攻击。

Microsoft Windows Vista之前的版本中的IPv4实现使用弱主机模型。Windows Vista和Windows Server 2008 TCP/IP堆栈支持IPv4和IPv6的强主机模型，并默认配置为使用。然而，它也可以配置为使用弱主机模型。

Linux中的IPv4实现默认使用弱主机模型。通过启用反向路径源验证，如RFC 1812中指定的rp_filter选项，一些发行版默认情况下会启用。这与强主机模型不完全相同，但可以保护典型的多宿主机免受相同类别的攻击。arp_ignore和arp_announce也可以用于调整此行为。

现代BSD（FreeBSD、NetBSD、OpenBSD和DragonflyBSD）都默认使用弱主机模型。OpenBSD自6.6-current版本起默认支持强主机模型，只有在禁用IP转发时才支持。启用IP转发时（以及旧版本中）通过其pf防火墙使用urpf-failed选项支持反向路径源验证，而FreeBSD、NetBSD和DragonflyBSD提供全局sysctl选项。

content: Label switching is a technique used in network relaying to address issues with traditional IP-table switching. It operates at the data link layer instead of the network layer, allowing for faster packet switching. Technologies such as MPLS and ATM utilize label switching. According to RFC 2475, examples of label switching models include Frame Relay, ATM, and MPLS, which allow for finer granularity in resource allocation and traffic management. Multilayer switching involves examining layer 3, layer 4, and layer 7 information in routing devices.

content: LANStar was a 2.56 Mbit/s twisted-pair local area network introduced by Northern Telecom in the '80s. It used existing PBX wiring for data transmission. Initially part of the PTE product, which included office automation apps, it was phased out when PCs and PC networking gained popularity. NT repackaged it as the PTE-S, a smaller version supporting up to 112 nodes. It was compatible with PC/XT, PC/AT, and MacII and supported NetBIOS, Banyan, Novell, and AppleTalk. LANStar was discontinued in 1990. Its name was derived from AT&T's StarLAN to piggyback on its publicity.
